PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) will be carried out in two phases. 
Phase 1: To finalize overall project concept and key parameters with government and the 
private sector based on selected products and respective analyses. Phase 2: Based on the 
agreements in phase 1 to (i) undertake due diligence covering technical, financial, economic, 
poverty and social and safeguards aspects in order to determine detailed project components; 
(ii) establish ownership by the government, the private sector, possible cofinanciers and other 
stakeholders of the design process and respective contributions; (iii) assess and agree with the 
government and the private sector on the scope of the proposed project, detailed components, 
implementation arrangements and financing mechanism; (iv) undertake capacity assessment of 
executing agency and implementing agencies; and (vi) collaborate  with  the Private Sector 
Operations Department on potential complementary investment activities.

for phase 2 will be determined based on the outcome of phase 1.

5.  Outline terms of reference for the PPTA consultants are described in paragraphs 6–10. 
The terms of reference below reflect the main responsibilities of the PPTA team members, i.e., 
team leader/agribusiness specialist, private sector development specialist, gender specialist, 
facilitator and agricultural value chain specialist for phase 1 and 2. The required technical 
expertise needed for phase 2 can only be determined based on the outcome of phase 1.  This is

Phase 1: Consultant terms of references 
Team Leader/Agribusiness Specialist (International, 5.5 person-months) 
6.  The team leader, in collaboration with the ADB task manager, will manage the overall 
design process and the work of the PPTA team members. This entails the guidance of the team 
members and coordination of the project design processes. During phase 1 the team leader will 
be responsible for (i) identification of products for commercial development  and respective 
analyses  as  well  as  identification  of  potential  markets  and/or  partners,  (ii)  identification  of 
successful private agribusinesses and their potential for up scaling, (iii) the preparation of draft 
project documents of overall project concept for discussion with the government, private sector 
and ADB; (iv) obtaining concept clearance and product agreement from government and private 
sector. Subsequently in phase 2, the team leader will be responsible for the preparation of the 
detailed project design report and its annexes, (ii) prepare work plan and consultation schedule, 
(iii) coordinate deliverables, (iv) analyze constraints for increased production and determine 
respective  support  mechanism,  (v)  prepare  the  detailed  design  and  monitoring  framework 
(DMF),  (vi)  prepare  project  performance  indicators.  The  team  leader  will  ensure  that  all 
stakeholders including farmers, agribusiness enterprises, service providers, government, other 
relevant agencies and development partners are consulted adequately.  
 
Private Sector Development Specialist (International, 2.5 person-months) 
7.  The private sector development specialist will  work with the team members and in 
particular with the agro industrial sector to identify interest and potential of the private sector for 
product expansion as well as current capacities and constraints for private sector participation, 
in particular in agri processing infrastructure investments relevant for increased production. In 
addition, the specialist will identify and analyze potential market entry strategies and partnership 
arrangements for selected products. Furthermore, the specialist will work with the financial 
sector  to  evaluate  and/or  develop  potential  financing  programs  which  could  be  extended 
through the commercial banking sector to private agribusinesses.  
 
Social, Poverty and Gender Specialist (International, 1 person-months) 
8.  The consultant will (i) collect available background data and (ii) develop and implement a 
stakeholder and community consultation plan. Based on agreed overall project concept and 
involved  stakeholders,  the  consultant  will  (i)  conduct  a  gender  analysis,  (ii)  prepare 
socioeconomic monitoring and management plans, (v) collect key sex-disaggregated baseline 
data to set appropriate gender targets. The gender targets will be further refined in phase 2 and 
finalized in the gender action plan. 
 
Facilitator (International, 0.5 person-months) 
9.  The consultant will facilitate the stakeholders’ workshops and support all stakeholder 
groups  to  achieve  consensus  on  overall  project  concept  design,  key  parameters  and  key 
products. 
 
Agricultural Value Chain Specialist (National, 3.0 person-months) 
10.  The specialist will be responsible for: (i) identifying a shortlist of agricultural products for 
priority attention under the project, (ii)  reviewing possible approaches to  enhanced private

sector  participation  in  agricultural  supply  chains;  (iii)  identifying  opportunities  for  building 
partnerships between agribusiness enterprises and their suppliers and customers; and (iv) 
identifying potential constraints for increased production. The overall objective is to determine 
an approach to improving value addition through increased private sector investment and agro-
industrial  and  marketing  operations,  in  partnership  with  farmers  and the  key  public  sector 
supporting institutions.   
 
Phase 2: Terms of reference for consultants to be determined based on outcome of 
phase 1. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
11.  The executing agency for the PPTA will be the Ministry of Finance. A decision will be 
made on the executing agency for the project during the course of the PPTA. The executing 
agency will provide counterpart staff and office facilities during the course of the PPTA. 
 
12.  The proposed TA will  be implemented from  30  March 2013 to 30  May 2014. The 
estimated implementation schedule is listed in Table A4.4.
